issue.title: Discrepancy between sample and user guide
issue.body:
The [user guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#running-tests-build-maven-engines-configure) indicates that both `junit-platform-surefire-provider` and `junit-jupiter-engine` should be dependencies of the `maven-surefire-plugin` plugin, and the code should just depend on `junit-jupiter-api` (for simple cases).

The sample [referenced](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5-samples/blob/r5.2.0/junit5-jupiter-starter-maven/pom.xml) by the user guide rather uses `junit-jupiter-engine` as a global dependency. 

The [current](https://github.com/junit-team/junit5-samples/blob/master/junit5-jupiter-starter-maven/pom.xml) sample depend globally on `junit-jupiter-api`, `junit-jupiter-engine` and `junit-jupiter-params`, and does not mention `junit-platform-surefire-provider` at all. I guess that the supplementary dependency on `junit-jupiter-params` is there because the test is parameterized. But what about the other differences? What is the recommended configuration for a simple project using junit5?

Can you possibly change or comment the sources of information so that they match or we understand why they differ?

body:
I'm still running all my tests with the engine as a dependency of the plugin (as described in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5-samples/issues/25) and have never had a problem.  As noted in that issue (and the one I submitted to change the JUnit 5 Users Guide), the primary benefit is that the engine's classes cannot accidentally be used by the test writer.  I haven't seen any of the issues predicted by @Tibor17.

The current inconsistency exists because at some point the change to the sample was "undone".  I still think this is a bad recommendation and I'd suggest that the best thing to do is to remove the sample and the Maven section (contents) of the Users Guide and replace them with a link to the ``maven-surefire-plugin``.  If Surefire really has specific requirements, shouldn't the configuration be documented there?

> I'm still running all my tests with the engine as a dependency of the plugin (as described in junit-team/junit5-samples#25) and have never had a problem.

@smoyer64, do you use the latest and greatest versions of the JUnit Platform within an IDE for those exact same projects, where the default version of the JUnit Platform supported by the IDE is lower than the version you are using in your Maven build?

I suggest still mentioning in the user guide (or in some other appropriate place) that the dependency to -engine can also be placed under the surefire-plugin, together with a dependency to -api for the code, and that solution is perhaps a tad bit more elegant but also longer, thus the shorter one is favored in the user guide. So that users know what the tradeoffs are.

@sbrannen - I suspect that my IDE has an older version of JUnit Platform as
I'm now using VS Code which uses a headless Eclipse under the covers.  It's
entirely possible that I've just been lucky so far (I haven't used the
newest JUnit 5 platform features that aren't compatible with the one
running in VS Code).  I'm also wondering if I would end up with the issues
that @Tibor17 describes if I enable concurrency (as you pointed out in
another issue, I'm doing just fine at the moment running tests
sequentially).

I should have done a better job separating my observations from my
recommendation.  My rationale for pointing the user at the
``maven-surefire-plugin`` documentation is that changes to the
``maven-surefire-plugin`` itself might make the text of the JUnit 5 Users
Guide inconsistent with the new behavior.  Anyway ... just my two cents!

EDIT: Sorry for the wonky formatting that came from responding via email!

> It's entirely possible that I've just been lucky so far

Indeed.

> My rationale for pointing the user at the `maven-surefire-plugin` documentation is that changes to the `maven-surefire-plugin` itself might make the text of the JUnit 5 Users Guide inconsistent with the new behavior. Anyway ... just my two cents!

Sure. We'll cash in on those $0.02.

@oliviercailloux, good points. 

We'll try to take that into consideration as well.

@smoyer64 
Do you need my or @sormuras  help?
We can change documentation if necessary.
Sometimes we have just a good luck because somebody finds out a noninvasive way.
@Tibor17 - not at the moment ... if I run into an issue I'll fall back to putting the engine in the ``<dependencies>`` section as you suggested all those months ago.
@smoyer64 I agree that we should point users to the Maven documentation. But I think there's value in having the basics documented in the User Guide just like we do for Gradle.
